paragraph: Uluru, also known as Ayers Rock, is a large sandstone monolith that is sacred to the Pitjantjatjara, the Aboriginal people of the area, known as the Aṉangu. It is one of the most important indigenous sites of the country, being a popular destination for tourists since the 1930s. The area around the formation is home to many springs, waterholes, rock caves and ancient paintings. Uluru is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

info.hints: Ayers Rock, Aboriginal, UNESCO World Heritage Site

paragraph: Sitting alongside a deep blue harbor, this performing arts center is one of the most recognizable modern architectural landmarks in the world. Its series of white sail-shaped roof shells houses multiple venues for concerts and theater.

info.hints: harbor, white sail-shaped shells, architectural, landmark

paragraph: Paradise Island is a vacation destination known for being home to the large Atlantis resort and casino. It is known for its expansive beaches great for tourists looking for guided activities like snorkeling and surfing.

info.hints: Vacation, island, Bahamas, beach

paragraph: Tomorrowland is an annual electronic music festival held each summer, known as one of the most iconic events of its kind in the world. It celebrates global dance music culture, and the signature view is huge fairytale themed main stage, decorated with moving parts, bright lights, and fireworks that illuminate the entire festival grounds.

info.hints: electronic music festival, annual summer event, fairytale themed festival, huge stage with fireworks

paragraph: The Parintins festival is a vibrant event that occurs every late June. Opposing teams present their bulls for judging over three nights. The first edition of this event was in 1965. While it has become a popular celebration of Amazonian folklore, its initial purpose was to raise funds for the construction of a cathedral.

info.hints: bulls, Amazonian, folklore, three nights, late June

paragraph: This place has three waterfalls that are together in one area. This waterfall is shaped like a horseshoe. A very old teacher was the first person to go down the waterfall in a barrel in 1901. She was 63 years old and she took her cat with her. The water is green color because of the minerals and rocks in it. People use the water for drinking and also for making electricity. If you try to go over the falls now, you will have to pay $10,000 because it is not legal.

info.hints: Horseshoe Falls, border of two countries, boat rides, casinos, honeymoon spot

paragraph: Every August, a city-wide celebration of beer (often at Golden Beach) turns the main venue a sea of massive beer tents. The air hums with energy, filled with the aroma of hops and sizzling street food. The star is the Tsingtao Brewery pavilion, where locals and visitors clink glasses with cheerful shouts of "Gan bei!", often drinking from towering beer sharers. This vibrant festival is a lively nod to the city's German-Chinese brewing history, visible in its old-town architecture.

info.hints: Tsingtao Brewery, August, The history of German concessions, coastal city, Gan bei

paragraph: Every winter, a northern city along a wide river that freezes solid transforms into a temporary “ice city” built from enormous blocks of river ice and packed snow. Full-size castles, temples, and towers are carved and lit from within by colorful lights, so visitors can wander glowing streets, slide down ice slides, and watch fireworks burst above neon-blue spires in temperatures far below freezing. What began as a small local ice-lantern fair has grown into one of the world’s largest winter festivals, drawing sculptors and tourists from across the region to this famously frigid destination.

info.hints: temporary “ice city”, world’s largest winter festivals, ice castles and temples

paragraph: Along one side of a wide river, a broad promenade runs past a row of grand early-20th-century banks, hotels, and trading houses built in ornate European styles. In the evening, crowds gather along the railings to watch sightseeing boats drift by and to photograph a dense forest of glass skyscrapers and a TV tower with glowing colored spheres across the water. Once the heart of a treaty-port financial district under foreign concessions, this historic waterfront is now a symbol of a megacity where colonial-era facades face a hyper-modern skyline, especially crowded at sunset and on humid summer nights.

info.hints: grand early-20th-century banks, financial district, historic riverfront

paragraph: This carnival is an annual three-day event in June which focuses on celebrating world cultures, folk music, and dance. It includes a traditional parade through the city center and features over 120 bands and 2000 dancers making it the largest festival in this country for world music.

info.hints: Copenhagen, annual three-day event, July, world cultures, parade, music

paragraph: This Christmas market dates back to the 16th century. Eight markets are located on well-known streets. There is something for everyone, from family to pet-friendly activities, to cultural experiences, and stalls with artisan-made goods

info.hints: 16th-century origin, cathedral, Alsace region, historic Christmas celebration

paragraph: Each fall, this old town at the foot of the mountains has a big holiday centered around its famous cathedral. People come from all over for church service in the morning, then the whole area turns into a street festival. There are stalls with churchkhela, other sweets, grilled food, and local wine, plus artists selling handmade stuff. Folk dancers and singers perform near the cathedral, and families walk through the narrow stone streets around it, just enjoying the atmosphere.

info.hints: old town at the foot of the mountains, famous cathedral, fall religious celebration, churchkhela and local wine stalls

paragraph: Oktoberfest is an annual event that takes place every October, seen as a massive festival on an open field where rows of large tents buzz with music, dancing, and clicks of huge mugs. Visitors dress in casual clothes, enjoy hearty dishes and frothy beer to celebrate the culture. The event attracts millions from around the world, transforming the city into a weeks long celebration of regional pride.

info.hints: beer, autumn festival, mugs, culture, regional celebration

paragraph: In this mountainous region, ancient monasteries cling to cliffsides over 400 meters high, accessible only by rope ladders until the 1920s. These sacred sites, built in the 14th century, house priceless Byzantine frescoes and manuscripts. The dramatic rock formations were created millions of years ago and have been inhabited by hermit monks seeking spiritual isolation since the 9th century.

info.hints: Meteora monasteries - region-specific, not city-specific, so city field left blank

paragraph: The majestic Buda Castle is one of the main symbols of the country. It dominates the city from the top of Várhegy hill, giving the opportunity to enjoy an amazing view. A first rudimental fortification of the castle dates back to the 14th century. After the Mongol tribes invaded the country, King Béla IV decided to build a shelter surrounded by walls. During the Renaissance, King Matthias undertook some changes to the castle that reflected the style of the time. When the city was occupied by the Ottomans between 1541 and 1686, the castle was destroyed. Eventually, the Habsburg gave a new castle to the city. The structure was built between 1714 and 1723 in Baroque style. During the revolt against the Habsburg regime in 1849, much of the castle was destroyed. It was reconstructed only after establishing a compromise with the Habsburg. After the German invasion during World War II, the castle was severely damaged once again. Reconstruction works started in 1950, following a design by architect István Janáki. During the reconstruction works, the ruins of the Renaissance period were found and integrated to the new complex. The castle's turbulent history reflects the different ups and downs in the history of the country.

info.hints: Buda, Várhegy, 14th century, King Béla IV, Renaissance, King Matthias, occupied by the Ottomans between 1541 and 1686, Habsburg, Baroque, German invasion during World War II, István Janáki

paragraph: Commissioned by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan I, the Red Fort is a 17th-century marvel on the banks of the Yamuna River. It was constructed after the emperor decided to shift the Mughal Empire’s capital from Agra to Delhi. Built from red sandstone and marble, the Red Fort was home to the Peacock Throne and is the site of the annual Indian Independence Day ceremony, during which the Prime Minister raises the national flag.

info.hints: Shah Jahan I, red sandstone, banks of River Yamuna, Indian Independence Day

paragraph: Diwali, known as the "Festival of Lights", is one of the most important festivals in the country and usually takes place in October. It is a representation of the triumph of the light over the darkness, of the good over the evil. The most recognizable image of the festival is the lines of the glowing lights and candles lightening up houses in the dark sky.

info.hints: Festival of Lights, diyas, victory of light over darkness

paragraph: For the first time in franchise history, the entire city erupted into celebrations as the home team lifted the championship trophy after a dramatic final match. With the win of RCB, Red and gold flags filled the stadium and the roar of the crowd echoed through MG Road well past midnight. Fans formed massive processions, singing the team anthem, while fireworks lit up the sky above the iconic cricket ground. Local cafes and pubs stayed open through the night, replaying the winning moment when the captain sealed the chase with a blistering cover drive. The victory parades the next morning drew lakhs of supporters.

info.hints: red and gold flags, MG Road celebrations, cricket ground, victory parade in Bengaluru, team anthem, first-ever championship win

paragraph: Gate of All Nations is part of a UNESCO World Heritage site, with ruins from before 500 BC, commissioned by the Xerxes for the Achaemenid Empire.

info.hints: UNESCO World Heritage, ruins from before 500 BC, Xerxes, Achaemenid Empire.

paragraph: Hafezieh, also knowns as the Tomb of Hafez, are monuments in memory of the poet Hafez, built in 1935 in his hometown to celebrate his life and influence on the world culture.

info.hints: poet Hafez, hometown, monument. tomb

paragraph: Hexagonal basalt columns rise like stepping-stones from the sea attracting tourists from across Europe

info.hints: basalt columns, Europe

paragraph: After climbing 414 steps up a narrow staircase, you can find a beautiful view of this city and fired clay tile rooftops.

info.hints: birthplace of the Renaissance, Michelangelo, leather goods, Tuscan cuisine

paragraph: A historical city that is an archaeological site today. This ancient Roman city was famously destroyed by the eruption of a volcano nearby and was buried in volcanic ashes, but preserved.

info.hints: City of Ruins, Mount Vesuvius, ashes,

paragraph: This Sea Fireworks Festival is a year-round spectacle, famous for its incredible sound. Set in a mountain-ringed bay, the natural acoustics create a booming stadium effect, earning it the title of #1 fireworks venue. The signature finale is the "Aerial Niagara," a massive cascade of light that fills the sky.

info.hints: Atami, fireworks, Japan

paragraph: In front of a busy urban train station, several streets meet at a single large intersection where traffic lights stop cars in every direction at once. When the walk signal turns on, hundreds of people surge into the road from all corners, crossing diagonally and straight ahead in a huge coordinated scramble that looks chaotic but somehow flows smoothly. Towering video screens, neon billboards, and a famous meeting spot with a statue of a loyal dog sit nearby, and many visitors watch the crowds from the second floor of a coffee shop overlooking the scene, filming the tide of pedestrians as it rises and falls with each light change.

info.hints: busy, train station, pedestrian crossing, neon billboards, major East Asian metropolis

paragraph: Charyn Canyon is a natural gorge carved by the Charyn River. Its red cliffs and towering rock spires create a landscape that draws hikers, photographers, and nature enthusiasts

info.hints: Valley of Castles, rock spires, Steppe region, nature destination, red cliffs, carved by river

paragraph: The donkey riding competition is a chaotic and joyous celebration during a religious festival. The air is filled with cheering crowds and it smells of sea salt in this town with no cars.

info.hints: town with no cars, religious festival

paragraph: Fort Jesus sits along the edge of the Indian Ocean, where the salty breeze mixes with the scent of old coral-stone walls. Built by the Portuguese in the late 1500s, the fort has a massive, uneven shape that resembles a person lying on their back when viewed from above. Walking inside, you hear echoes from centuries of trade, battles, and cultural exchanges—Arab, Portuguese, Omani, and Swahili influences all layered in one place. The thick battlements, rusted cannons facing the sea, and narrow arched passages create the feeling of stepping into a living museum that watched over East Africa’s coast for more than 400

info.hints: coastal fort, Indian Ocean breeze, coral-stone walls, Portuguese 16th century, Swahili coast, Mombasa Old Town, battlements, cannons

paragraph: Great migration is the movement of wild-beasts around cycles reserves driven by search of fresh grazing and water, and Masaai Mara is one of the best destination to observe this phenomenon and the incredible wildlife.

info.hints: Great migration, Maasai Mara, wildbeast

paragraph: It is an extinct volcano that is among the tallest in Africa. To the local community it is the home of their god 'Ngai'. At the top of the mountain is ice and a bit of snow. The mountain can be seen from nearby locations very early in the morning as the air is dense and crisp.

info.hints: Ngai, Africa

paragraph: Old Town is a walk through time. The narrow streets filled with intricately carved wooden doors and swahili style balconies. The humid air is filled with scents of cardamon, tumeric, coffee and other spices from the near spice market.

info.hints: spice market, swahili

paragraph: The historic town Mnarani Ruins represents the remnants of the early Swahili civilization in East Africa, in one of the regions near the Indian Ocean. The origins of the town are dated back to the 14th century where grand mosques and even tombs were established. Unfortunately, in the 17th century it met its decline where conflicts and Portuguese incursions destabilized many the town.

info.hints: Swahili civilization, East Africa,  Indian Ocean

paragraph: Bukchon Hanok village is a historic neighborhood. It's known for traditional korean houses dating back to Joseon dynasty. Blending the past with the present, it's popular for Michelin restaurants and trending cafes.

info.hints: joseon dynasty, hanok, historic neighborhood, trendy cafe

paragraph: The Independence Day Parade is a colorful annual celebration held every July 26, where the entire capital buzzes with music, laughter, and the smell of grilled street food drifting through the humid air. The event moves along Tubman Boulevard, lined with red-and-white flags and crowds dressed in bright lappa prints. Brass bands from local schools march proudly, their drumbeats echoing between the buildings while cultural dancers perform traditional steps that shake the ground with each stomp.

info.hints: July 26, Monrovia, Tubman Boulevard, Liberian flags, lappa prints, brass bands, Independence Day parade, cultural dancers, Liberian patriotism, giant street celebration

paragraph: The Rainforest World Music Festival is a three-day music festival celebrating the diversity of music. It includes music workshops, cultural and craft displays, food stalls, and a rainforest stage setting.

info.hints: indigineous musicians, sape performance, bamboo percussion, ethnic tribes, annual music festival

paragraph: Chichen Itza is a historical site located on the Yucatan Peninsula. Considered to be one of the seven wonders of the world, the archeological site dates back to the the 5th century AD. A pilgrimage site for the ancient Mayans that built it, the city is a collection of different temples and palaces that nobles and priests used for administrative work and religious ceremonies.

info.hints: Mexico, ancient Mayans, seven wonders of the world, archeological site

paragraph: Swayambhu is a famous hilltop site where visitors walk up a very long stone staircase where many monkeys sit along the steps and roam. At the top, there is a large white stupa with a golden tower and painted eyes that look over the city. People walk around the stupa while spinning numerous prayer wheels. Swayambhu has a very calm and tranquil feeling with bells and bhajan in the background.

info.hints: stone staircase, monkeys, golden spire, painted eyes

paragraph: Every autumn, this city transforms into a sea of orange as the world's largest celebration of the royal family takes place. Canals fill with boats, electronic music echoes through the streets, and locals don traditional costumes to honor their monarch's birthday. The festival attracts over 600,000 visitors who come to experience the unique blend of historical pageantry and modern party culture.

info.hints: King's Day (Koningsdag) is a distinctly Dutch celebration centered in Amsterdam

paragraph: Olumo Rock Tourist Complex stands as a top destination that combines natural beauty, historical significance, and tourist attraction. Located in Ikija, Abeokuta, Ogun State close to the renowned Itoku Adire Market it provides visitors with a memorable mix of adventure, cultural exploration, and relaxation.

info.hints: Ogun State close to the renowned Itoku Adire Market

paragraph: The Tower of Belém (or Belém Tower) was built on the Tagus River in the 16th century and served as an embarkation and disembarkation for explorers. It is built out of limestone and incorporates Moorish architecture. It serves as a symbol for Europe's Age of Discovery and is a UNESCO World Heritage Site as of 1983.

info.hints: Tagus River, Europe, Moorish, UNESCO World Heritage Site

paragraph: Saint Basil’s Cathedral is known for its brightly colored onion-shaped domes. It represents growing power under Ivan IV's rule. Visitors can wander Red square, enjoy local street foods, and take in architecture set against the Kremlin

info.hints: onion-shaped domes, UNESCO world heritage site, historic cobblestone square, military victory

paragraph: Crater Lakes are rarely seen around the world. This is due to the process it takes to be formed. One example of them is found in East Africa, on the top of volcanic mountain Bisoke called Bisoke Crater Lake. Generally, Crater lakes are formed after volcanic eruptions. Crater lakes are primarily formed through volcanic activity, with the process typically involving the creation of a depression (a crater or a larger caldera) that subsequently fills with water. What attracts about these types of lakes includes their hilly location and how they are formed.

info.hints: eruption, volcanic, rwanda, crater, lakes, mountain top, nothern rwanda

paragraph: Every year in September, thousands gather to witness the naming of baby mountain gorillas born in the country's national parks. The event is a grand celebration of conservation efforts and a unique spectacle of culture and wildlife preservation, often including international dignitaries and performers. The air is filled with anticipation and the vibrant colors of traditional attire.

info.hints: Kwita Izina, mountain gorillas, conservation efforts, Volcanoes National Park, traditional Rwandan attire

paragraph: The Genocide Memorial sits on a hillside in Gisozi, honoring over one million victims of the 1994 Genocide Against the Tutsi. The site features permanent exhibitions, gardens of remembrance with mass graves holding over 250,000 victims, and a children's memorial with photographs and personal belongings. A Wall of Names displays thousands of victims' identities. The memorial serves as both an educational center and a place for reflection, documenting the tragedy and Rwanda's journey toward reconciliation.

info.hints: Kigali, 1994, genocide memorial, Gisozi, Rwanda, mass graves, reconciliation, East Africa, Tutsi, educational center, hillside memorial

paragraph: This is the annual commemoration period observed for 100 days starting on April 7th. The nation engages in deep reflection, mourning, and remembrance of the 1994 Genocide. The period features official opening ceremonies, a "walk to remember," and public testimony, emphasizing unity and a commitment to never allowing such atrocities to happen again.

info.hints: 100 days of mourning, April 7th, remembrance, "walk to remember," Kwibuka, unity

paragraph: Contains Flower Dome, which holds Guinness world record for largest glass greenhouse in the world opened in 2012. It has over 1.5 million plants from around the world. Its design draws inspiration from the Orchid, the country's national flower.

info.hints: Orchid, cloud forest, supertree

paragraph: Voortrekker Monument is a granite structure with great historical meaning, as it was built to commemorate the Vootrekkers who left Cape Colony. It was designed by the architect Gerard Moerdijik.

info.hints: Monument, Colony, Voortrekker

paragraph: Every summer, thousands of people pack into the narrow streets of this small town to basically have the world’s biggest food fight. A truck rolls in loaded with overripe tomatoes, and as soon as the signal goes off, everyone starts launching them at each other. Within minutes, the whole street turns into a red, squishy mess, and people are slipping around laughing while firefighters stand by to hose everything down afterward. It’s chaotic, loud, and weirdly fun for something that’s literally just strangers throwing tomatoes at each other.

info.hints: overripe tomatoes, narrow streets, Spanish town, truck loaded with tomatoes, food fight, turned into a red mess, firefighters hosing down, summer event

paragraph: It is the tallest mountain in Africa with a height of 5,895 meters above sea level and it is found in East Africa. It can be seen from Amboseli National Park, and also from the national park in the neighboring countries. It is believed that Johannes Rebmann was the first European to report the mountain's existence, in 1848. It has two peaks named by the Chagga as Kibo and Mawenzi.

info.hints: height of 5,895 meters, East Africa, seen from Amboseli National Park, Johannes Rebmann, two peaks named by the Chagga

paragraph: The Hot Air Balloon Festival is a cultural and adventure festival. It is centered around hot air balloon flights, which are a highlight of the event. The festival also includes live music, cultural performances, traditional food markets, and night glow shows where balloons light up in sync with music after dark.  The hot air balloon rides soaring above stunning rock formations, ancient cave dwellings, and picturesque valleys promise an experience that will stay etched in your memories forever.

info.hints: rock formations, caves, valleys

paragraph: When you walk near this famous clock tower, you get why everyone keeps taking photos of it. The thing looks even more dramatic in person than in all the pictures online. The huge clock faces stand out against the old stone, and when the bells hit the hour, the sound carries across Westminster. The whole area has this mix of history and politics baked into it, causing tourists to stop right in the middle of the sidewalk to stare up at it like it’s their first time seeing a clock in real life.

info.hints: famous clock tower, bells hit the hour, Westminster, old stone, tourists taking photos

paragraph: Often heralded as the home of motor racing, Silverstone saw one of F1's most iconic drives in 2008 where Lewis Hamilton won by over a minute in inclement weather conditions, lapping almost 2-3s faster than other drivers at times.

info.hints: Silverstone, home of motor racing, Lewis Hamilton

paragraph: Forest Park should be better known.  It is twice as large as New York City's Central Park, and contains magnificent cultural institutions such as the Art Museum, the world-famous Zoo, the History Museum and the Muny, an outdoor opera stage, just to name a few.  Forest Park's origins stem from the 1904 World's Fair.  All the exhibition buildings were sited in a bucolic green space that was, at the time, far from the city proper.  While the World's Fair structures were mainly temporary, one such building was built to last, on the condition that it became the Art Museum, with free public admission forever.  Many of the other institutions share that generosity of spirit, with the zoo and history museum also having free admission, and even the Muny keeping a section of free seats on a first-come, first-served basis.

info.hints: 1904 Worlds Fair, Forest Park, the Muny, the world-famous Zoo

paragraph: Just before sunrise in early October, hundreds of hot-air balloons lift together in a coordinated “mass ascension” in a desert field. The Sandia Mountains blush pink on the horizon as the balloons float over the Rio Grande, and by evening the tethered “glow” turns the field into a garden of lanterns.

info.hints: mass ascension, balloon, color, Sandia Mountains, Rio Grande, Zia sun symbol, October, hot-air balloons

paragraph: Picnic Day is the city’s most famous annual event, rooted in its namesake university and the traditions that have developed over time. The town’s biking culture and the everyday presence of cows help define the character of the Aggies celebration. Thousands of visitors and alumni return for the parade, student-run showcases, and the lively parties near and around campus.

info.hints: biking culture, cows, university, Aggies

paragraph: This is a national park internationally recognized for its granite cliffs, waterfalls, clear streams, groves of giant sequoia, lakes, mountains, meadows, glaciers, and biological diversity.

info.hints: National Park, California, granite cliffs

paragraph: Fallingwater is a house located in the mountains, designed by American architect Frank Lloyd Wright (1867-1959) for the Kaufmann family in 1935. Fallingwater exemplify the harmonious union of art and nature.allingwater is surrounded by 5,100 acres of natural land, streams and trails known as the Bear Run Nature Reserve

info.hints: Architecture, Frank Lloyd Wright, Kaufmann

paragraph: Every September, the Broadway Flea market & Grand Auction fills the streets around Times Square with theatre fans, performers and producers from all over the world. Hundreds of booths arranged by theatre or collectors offering everything from stage decoration to playbills with signatures.

info.hints: Broadway, Times Square, theatre

paragraph: Mount Rainier is a very famous mountain with two main hiking entrances that people can register for entry or walk-on to. There is a lot of natural vegetation that grows on the mountain and it is also home to wild animals like mountain goats and chipmunks.

info.hints: Mountain, Washington, volcano, PNW, hiking

paragraph: The Congress Avenue Bridge is home to thousands of bats each evening from spring to fall. Visitors watch the sunset flight from the bridge or riverbanks, with the bats swirling overhead above Lady Bird Lake in downtown

info.hints: bat bridge, lady bird lake, downtown, sunset, riverbank

paragraph: Built in 1991, the World's Tallest Thermometer is a quintessential part of any drive from Los Angeles to Las Vegas. This 134 feet tall, functioning thermometer structure commemorates the hottest day recorded in Death Valley.

info.hints: thermometer, Death Valley, 134 feet tall, 1991, Los Angeles, Las Vegas
